p: The compounds 1, 3, 5, 6, 7, 12 and 13 were predicted to bind in the polymerase domain: 1 is located in the RdRp active site, in the palm domain; 3 and 6 in the interface domain and 5, 7, 12 and 13 in the fingers domain (Fig. 3d). The binding to this polymerase domain might interfere with the viral RNA synthesis (Velthuis et al. 2014). On the other hand, the compounds 2, 4, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 14 were predicted to bind to the RdRp NiRAN domain (Fig. 3d). This domain is not part of the RdRp catalytic site, but it is essential for the virus due to potential functions that may include nucleic acid ligation, mRNA capping and protein-primed RNA synthesis (Lehmann et al. 2015).
